profileText: A Representative from North Carolina; born in Gaston, Northampton County, N.C., January 25, 1788; attended Warrenton Academy; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1810 and commenced practice in Warrenton, N.C.; member of the State house of representatives in 1814 and 1815; elected as a Republican to the Fourteenth Congress to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Nathaniel Macon; reelected as a Republican to the Fifteenth, Sixteenth, and Seventeenth Congresses, elected as a Crawford Republican to the Eighteenth Congress, and as a Jacksonian to the Nineteenth Congress; and served from February 7, 1816, to March 3, 1827; chairman, Committee on Expenditures in the Department of the Treasury (Eighteenth Congress), Committee on Public Expenditures (Nineteenth Congress); declined to be a candidate for reelection in 1826; returned to his plantation; member of the State senate 1833-1844; member of the State constitutional convention in 1835; again elected to the State senate in 1850 and chosen its president; president of the State secession convention in 1861; died in Warren County, N.C., December 18, 1873; interment in a private cemetery at his home, ``Poplar Mount,'' about twelve miles from Warrenton, Warren County, N.C.

note.content: Elected to fill vacancy caused by resignation of Nathaniel Macon, and took his seat February 7, 1816.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Edwards, Weldon Nathaniel. Memoir of Nathaniel Macon, of North Carolina. Raleigh: Raleigh Register Steam Power Press, 1862.

researchRecord.name: 1800-1870, 21 items.
researchRecord.description: The Weldon N. Edwards Collection contains scattered correspondence and papers concerning his entrance into politics, the Civil War, Reconstruction, and the Democratic Party.

researchRecord.name: In the Katherine Clark Pendleton Conway Collection, 1769-1877, 2200 items.
researchRecord.description: The collection contains papers of Weldon N. Edwards and includes correspondence (1817-1873) dealing mainly with politicians such as James Buchanan, Lewis Cass, Henry Clay, Nathaniel Macon, Willie Mangum, and David S. Reid; elections, especially 1840, 1852, and the Democratic convention of 1860; and issues such as the Missouri Compromise, surplus revenue (1836), state legislative instruction of U.S. senators (1839), free suffrage, cabinet of Franklin Pierce, and whether the Secession Convention should be reconvened to legislate in 1862, with advice from Gov. Z. B. Vance, William A. Graham, Kenneth Rayner, Thomas Ruffin, Walter L. Steele, Henry T. Clark, Daniel W. Courts, Bedford Brown. Correspondents also include William Gaston, discussing religious requirements of officeholders (1833), Bedford Brown, James Buchanan, John W. Ellis, W. W. Holden, William R. King, R. M. Saunders, William Smith, and Richard Dobbs Spaight, Jr., with copies of correspondence between Daniel Webster and John Randolph of Roanoke (1829). There are personal letters from Nathaniel Macon; letters from Thomas Hart Benton about his sketch of Macon; and family letters to Edwards's great-nephew, Marmaduke J. Hawkins at University of Virginia (1870-1871). Business papers include receipts (1816-1821, 1849-1872); slave bills of sale (1820-1857); and estate papers and/or wills for Nathaniel, William, and Benjamin Edwards, father-in-law Marmaduke Norfleet, Sr. (Halifax Co., d. 1818), Marmaduke Norfleet, Jr. (d. 1830), Benjamin Williamson, and Nathaniel Macon (d. 1837), with guardian papers for Lucy S. Norfleet (Edwards), Weldon N. Edwards, and Edwin Yancey. Miscellaneous papers include printed speech by John Randolph of Roanoke, annotated by him (1828), and various election returns (1814-1852, 1861). Belonging to G. W. Johnston of Greenville are a postwar memorandum and recipe book and a volume containing autographs of prisoners at Ft. Warren, Boston Harbor, including North Carolinians captured at Ft. Hatteras, former U.S. naval officers from the South, and prominent citizens of Maryland (1861). Also daybook (1831-1834) of Robert Leckie, Washington, D.C., businessman concerned with real estate, brickyards, and canal building.

researchRecord.name: 1825-1868, 85 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Weldon N. Edwards contain plantation diary entries (1825-1835) record weather, work, annual crop totals, some slaves; also stud records (1827-1844), remedies for animal diseases, and blacksmith accounts (1834). Correspondence (1852-1868) includes letters from Thomas Ruffin urging appointment of William Eaton, Jr., as federal judge; also letters about sale of slaves in Nathaniel Macon's estate, about Edwards's memoir of Macon (published in 1861), and the death of Capt. Chalmers Glenn at Battle of South Mountain, Md. (1862). Also rough drafts of two speeches by William Eaton at convention of 1865 and manuscript arithmetic book.

researchRecord.name: 1816-1870, 49 items.
researchRecord.description: The Weldon N. Edwards Collection contains political correspondence, including letters from many prominent politicians, especially John Randolph of Roanoke, Thomas Ruffin, and James Buchanan. Topics addressed range widely and include congressional events of the late 1820s and Democratic Party affairs of the 1840s. There are no papers relating to Edwards's activities as a member of the North Carolina constitutional convention of 1835, or to his service as president of the state secession convention, 1861-1862.
